dc:description: The relationship between NDUFS4 and Leigh syndrome spectrum was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of February 11, 2019. 18 articles were reviewed. NDUFS4 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Leigh syndrome spectrum in 1998 (Van den Heuvel et al 1998 PMID: 9463323). At least 12 unique variants predicted to cause a loss of or reduced function of the protein have been reported in ClinVar, suggesting homozygous loss of function is the mechanism of disease for this gene. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 6 probands with Leigh syndrome spectrum in 6 publications (PMID 27079373, 14765537, 27671926, 24020637, 22326555, 12616398). This gene-disease association is supported by protein interaction, expression, alterations in patient cell lines, and animal models. In summary, there is definitive evidence to support the relationship between NDUFS4 and autosomal recessive Leigh syndrome spectrum. More than three years have elapsed from the first proposal of the association to reach a definitive classification. This classification was approved by the NICHD U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on February 11, 2019 (SOP Version 6).

evidence.dc:description: Utilized model scoring system developed for Leigh syndrome experimental evidence

Model system demonstrated biochemical abnormalities consisted with Leigh syndrome reduced Complex I activity),neuropathological evidence in histology, along with neurocognitive and developmental symptoms (decreased lifespan, locomotor defects, and feeding difficulties).
evidence.rdfs:label: NDUFS4 Fly knockdown

evidence.dc:description: Utilized model scoring system developed for Leigh syndrome experimental evidence

Model system demonstrated biochemical abnormalities consisted with Leigh syndrome (lactic acidemia, reduced Complex I activity, and defect in C1 assembly) along with neurocognitive and developmental symptoms (progressive encephalopathy, ataxia, hypotonia, lethargy, and failure to thrive).
evidence.rdfs:label: NDUFS4 Exon 2 knockout Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Utilized model scoring system developed for Leigh syndrome experimental evidence
Model system demonstrated MRI findings consistent with human Leigh syndrome.
evidence.rdfs:label: NDUFS4 exon 2 knock out mouse (MRI findings)

evidence.dc:description: More than one cell culture model with different mutations or gene disruptions showing mitochondrial dysfunction.

Mitochondria isolated from cultured skin fibroblasts of  four patients with confirmed NDUFS4 mutations and described as having Leigh-like syndrome demonstrated reduced complex 1 activity, decreased levels of fully-assembled complex I, and the presence of a non-functional lower molecular weight sub complex
evidence.rdfs:label: NDUFS4 Assembly defects

evidence.dc:description: The encoded protein interacts with 10+ gene products whose dysfunction is known to cause Leigh syndrome.

NDUFS4 encodes an 18-kd subunit of complex 1 of the mitochondrial respiratory chain (Papa 1996) According to Leigh map, at least 19 other complex 1 subunits (Zhu 2016; PMID: 27509854)) have been implicated in causing Leigh syndrome (Rahman 2017 PMID: 27977873).
evidence.rdfs:label: Complex 1 structure

evidence.dc:description: The Human Protein Atlas (Uhlen et al 2015; PMID: 25613900) demonstrates that NDUFS4 protein is ubiquitously expressed (https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000164258-NDUFS4/tissue). Expression in the brain has been shown in the cerebral cortex, hippocampus, caudate, and cerebellum. Points can be awarded as this expression profile is consistent with areas of pathology in Leigh-like syndrome.
evidence.rdfs:label: Human Atlas Brain expression

evidence.dc:description: This mutation is a Hutterite founder mutation and has been seen in five other affected patients of Hutterite descent.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 4 (Lamont)
evidence.detectionMethod: A genome-wideSNP genotyping using the human GeneChip Mapping 10K 2.0 SNPgenotyping array followed by identity-by-descent mapping using Homozygosity-Mapper . This analysis identified a single regionwhere all three affected individuals shared greater than 50 conse-cutive homozygous genotypes ; NDUFS4 was PCR amplified  and Sanger sequenced with the ABI BigDye Termi-nator Cycle Sequencing Kit v1.1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: MRI of the brain and spinal cord showed a bilateral, symmetrical pattern of brainstem lesions (T2 hyperintense, T1 hypointense with restricted diffusion) involving the medulla, cerebral peduncles, tegmentum of the midbrain, and spinal cord.

evidence.rdfs:label: Benit Patient II-2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Brain CT scan showed cortical atrophyand bilateral hypodensity of the pedoncles and striatum, suggestive of Leigh syndrome

evidence.dc:description: This is a frameshift mutation; On a protein level, the c.462delA deletion led to a complete lack of NDUFS4 peptide in isolated mitochondria

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2 (Assereto)
evidence.detectionMethod: single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) array-based homozygosity mapping study (Illumina) identified three loci harboring stretches of consecutive homozygous markers on chromosome 5, 19 and 21 and including 257 genes  Mutational screening of known disease genes led to the identification of a homozygous c.462delA mutation in NDUFS4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: MRI axial T2‐weighted images showed symmetric hyper-intensity involving the tegmentum of the brainstem bilaterally, along the course of the medial longitudinal fascicle. There is also bilateral hyperintensity of the substantia nigra and subthalamic nucleus.

evidence.rdfs:label: Assouline Patient 7
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Brain MRI consistent with Leigh syndrome

evidence.dc:description: This mutation is a frameshift mutaion

evidence.rdfs:label: Index case (Ortigoza-Escobar)
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: MRI demonstrated bilateral and symmetric T2 signal hyper-intensity in the globus pallidus, putamen, cerebral peduncles, medulla oblongata and cervical spinal cord.

evidence.dc:description: This mutation leads to a premature stop codon.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1 (Budde)
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: MRI showed bilateral lesions in the basal ganglia reaching down into the medulla oblongata, and cerebral atrophy
